story:
Journalism Research Trip to Fort Jackson

In April, 2012, I received the news that my husband was going to war.

  • In August, my husband left for premobilization. On December 21st our son was born. On December 27 my husband flew into Afghanistan.

What followed was the hardest year of my life, as I watched my loved one complete missions in a war zone while I cuddled with our son and wondered if his daddy was going to make it home. 

  • Since then, I have been on a quest to understand more of the Soldier's life, from the first days of training as a recruit, to post-deployment days and the struggles of leaving the Armed Forces. I've witnessed firsthand the stress and the joys. There are moments that are downright terrifying and moments that will keep you laughing for years. 
  • Many Americans never get to see or understand what their heroes are doing, every single day for them. And how maybe, the heroism isn't always in the newsworthy purple medal moments (although, the sacrifice certainly is noteworthy), but rather in the day-to-day drudgery doing the work that no one else wants to with less resources than everyone else has. My passion is to share a glimpse of that by writing an essay dealing with the beginning of it all, Basic Training (The Army's version of Boot Camp), where recruits get their first taste of what it's like to be in the Army. 
  • This summer, I began my war novel, "The Boy Who Lost His Enemy." As my main character approaches enlisting and being sent to Army Basic Training, I need to know what basic training is like. So my research will be beneficial for much more than just this essay. However, In this essay let me take you to the sights, sounds and smells of recruits in the beginnings of their military journeys. 

I have been granted the opportunity to observe Army Basic Training first hand at Fort Jackson, South Carolina.
  • I'm eager to get my boots on the ground, so to speak, and capture the grittiness of training men and women to kill, and not die.

What I Need & What You Get

My Trip Costs

  • Car Rental - $200.00 (Deemed wiser and more cost effective than taking our single family car with 100,000+ miles on it.)
  • Gas - $150.00 (600+ miles of driving.)
  • Hotel - $350.00
  • Food - $150.00
  • Total = $850
  • I've been able to raise $200 already. Please help me raise the remaining $650.

What You Get

  • You'll receive an artistic essay complete with pictures and you also get the chance to share in the making of a novel!

  • Contributions are processed through paypal. Feel free to use either your paypal account or a credit card. For your convenience, Paypal will process credit cards without you needing to have a Paypal account. Please let me know if you have any questions!

  • All funds will go towards this trip, even if the total goal is not met, OR if the funds exceed the requested amount. Being able to lengthen my stay at Fort Jackson, pay for childcare for my son and purchase a better camera would be significant help with this project!

The Impact

  • Ever seen a soldier at the airport and been at a loss of what to do? Say thank you? Give them space to reunite with family? Stare? 
  • Ever seen an army duffle bag sitting next to a homeless guy on the street and wondered how it got there? How he got there?
  • Ever teared up at the homecoming commercials and wondered if that's what its really like? 
  • Ever wished others would understand what your military life was like? But been unable to explain? Ever been hurt or angered by the careless things people say and do?
  • Ever been shocked by the number of homeless and jobless servicemembers? Been shocked by the number who are committing suicide, every day? 

I have an inside glimpse of how war and training affects Soldiers. 

And it's not what we think. 
  • Men and women enlist, deploy and return home without much of America realizing or understanding the impact of war. 
  • But sometimes the struggles aren't from flesh wounds. Separation, high stress-levels, and rationed resources can stretch marriages to the breaking point, can cause veterans to struggle to hold down jobs, and can lead to despair and suicide. 
  • BASIC TRAINING IS WHERE THE MILITARY JOURNEY BEGINS.
This essay will help bridge the gap between our fighting men and women's realities and American understanding. The more we understand, the greater difference we can make. 

    Risks & Challenges

    HURDLES

    •  This will be my first, but not last, significant research project, but I'm excited and preparing thoroughly. 

    PAST HURDLES I'VE JUMPED

    • I've been a freelance writer since November 2013 and have received complements from many. My editors keep asking me when I'll have my next article ready! Visit "Off The Grid News" (http://www.offthegridnews.com/author/priscillas...) and "Thalo Artist Community" (http://www.thalo.com/articles/view/903/residenc...) to see some of my work
    Researching, exploring and following fascinating leads is a passion of mine, second only to my joy in crafting words into stories (both fiction and nonfiction). This coupled with my determination to make a difference inside and outside of the military community ensures thorough research and gripping writing.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Even if you can't contribute, please consider helping by sharing my story and my need. Thank you!

      • Facebook, Twitter, blogs, Google Plus, email and face-to-face are all great ways to share my story. Your support solidifies my reputation for excellence and encourages others to connect and get involved. 

      And that's all there is to it!

      I'll be sharing updates and will keep everyone informed as we go along. I would be delighted if you would connect with me on Facebook, Twitter or at my blog. Thank you!

      Many thanks to the United States Military for the above images and to Sadie Ermol (www.designedbyae.com) for the outstanding video filming and design!

      Contact me at pinkcombatboots@gmail.com with any questions or comments! I look forward to hearing from you!

      And, yes, in August 2013, my husband came home safe and sound!

story:
It's Hard Getting Started as a New Author

Imagine for the last 8 years you have been writing a short novel with free time you find here and there between classes at school, and long work hours at multiple jobs and internships.  After so long creating your masterpiece, you have a great desire to get published and let the world enjoy your work.

If you're just starting out as an author, you know this feeling all too well.

Luckily, it's not very hard to get published now in the digital age.  You can release your book for Kindle, Nook and as an Apple iBook without too much of an investment.

After your book gets listed, your book sales start to trickle in slowly over time.  After a few months you begin to realize that, after all that hard work, only a few people get the opportunity to even stumble onto your book and even fewer will provide a review.

Every day, thousands of new authors are forced to handle their own social marketing, buy into expensive advertising campaigns, and enter as many competitions as they can to get even the slightest amount of exposure for their book.

I have decided it's time to help my fellow eBook authors get exposure and reviews for their new releases by forming a tight-knit online community in which we can share our creations with one another, provide honest and supportive reviews, and help get every new eBook release the exposure it deserves online.

Let's Build an eBook Author Community

In order to help as many new eBook authors as we can, there are some fundamental pieces we need in order to get started.  All together, the starting costs will add up to a bit over $20,000.  I have decided to raise half of this amount here on Indiegogo and I will take care of the rest that is needed.  Here are a few of the detailed expenses:

  • ~$12,000 - Professional social community website design and development
  • $1,500 - Facebook page and app integration
  • $6,500 - Launch marketing budget for 6 months
  • $120 - Domain name and server hosting

The Mission

To raise awareness of new book releases, generate more sales, and get positive reviews for new and existing authors everywhere.

Great Exposure for New Authors

There are many ingredients that go into a successful new book launch, many of which are very costly, like marketing, or have slim chances of success, like winning a writing competition.  The best way to make a good first impression in the major eBook stores is to get many sales and good reviews from your readers.  Here is how I propose we help authors get their big start:

  1. Free accounts with profiles and book listings for authors
  2. Review Credits
    • Buy, read and review a member's book to receive a Review Credit
    • Members will buy, read and review your book in return
  3. Share Credits
    • Share a member's book to earn Share Credits
    • Members will share your book in return

The Impact

This is a fairly large project but I have plenty of experience working with various new web communities and I look forward to handling the operation of the website and facilitating an active and growing community of new authors!  Working together, every new book released can be reviewed, get a special launch page, and be shared by many members on social networks and through many other various marketing channels.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are an author or know other authors who would be interested in having their book listed, reviewed, and shared on our community website after we get up and running, please share this Indiegogo project and help spread the word to make this project a success.

story:
The campaign was a success! The book comes out on November 5, 2012! Subscribe for free updates at http://www.robotswillstealyourjob.com

The Story

You are about to become obsolete. You think you are special, unique, and that whatever it is that you are doing is impossible to replace. You are wrong. As we speak, millions of algorithms created by computer scientists are frantically running on servers all over the world, with one sole purpose: do whatever you used to do, but better.

That is the argument for a phenomenon called technological unemployment, one that is pervading modern society. But is that really the case? Or is it just a futuristic fantasy? What will become of us in the coming years, and what can we do to prevent a catastrophic collapse of society?

This book will explore the impact that technological advances will have on our lives, how does that affect employment, the nature of work and why we work, what it means to be happy, and provide suggestions on how to avoid a systemic collapse.

Full title: Robots will steal your job, but that's OK: how to survive the economic collapse and be happy

Reviews

"Understanding the complex relationship between automation and jobs re- quires empirical analysis and a nuanced inquiry. Federico Pistono’s book is a unique and fearless contribution to the ongoing conversation on this topic. He approaches the issues with a perspective that reflects his love of both people and technology […] Relentlessly constructive, optimistic, and controversial. Read it, then agree or disagree with various points, but join the dialog!"
– Neil Jacobstein Co-chair AI and Robotics, Singularity University

 

"This book is a smart, humorous, but thorough, and potentially important approach to a fundamental question of our time."
– David Orban CEO of dotSUB Director of the
Singularity Institute for Artificial Intelligence Europe

Why this book?

We are at a turning point in our society, but one of the greatest challenges and dangers that we face is relegated to small academic circles and technically minded people. This is wrong, because this transformation will affect us all. My reason to write this book is to give to the larger public the tools to understand what is coming and not feel impotent when things turn really bad.

T-Shirts

After many requests, here they are: ROBOTS STOLE MY JOB awesome T-Shirts, for boys and for the ladies ♥

VISIT THE SHOP
http://federicopistono.spreadshirt.com

 

Book development

  • Step 0: collect information about the topics and write general outline of the book -- done
  • Step 1: interview with experts in the fields of artificial intelligence, robotics, economics, anthropology and sociology
  • Step 2: first draft
  • Step 3: proofreading with the help of a professional (this is what the money is for)
  • Step 4: formatting and optimisation for mobi (Kindle), EPUB (iOS and Android) and PDF (PC and Mac)
  • Step 5: early release for backers only (to show some love ^^)
  • Step 6: Design T-Shirts and find a proper manufacturer (only good quality shirts will be chosen)
  • Step 7: print and send limited editions paperback and hardcover for backers, along with t-shirts
  • Step 8: release ebook on Amazon and iBooks
  • Step 9: find publisher for mass physical distribution
  • Step 10: if all goes well and interest is high, conduct a survey and translate the book in the most requested languages
  • Step 11: free PDF under a Creative Commons licence on the website, some time after the general release.

For more information, visit http://www.robotswillstealyourjob.com

Distribution

The book will be released early for backers only. After that the general release on Amazon and iBooks is scheduled.

However, I think this information should be accessible to all, so I decided that some time the general distribution, a free PDF under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 License will also be released on the website.

story:
Who & What I'm About

Hi there and welcome to my Indigogo campaign page for raising funds to create podcasts of short stories by African writers.

The idea for this project came about when I created podcasts of some of the stories which are part of my upcoming short story collection.  The idea was to build up an audience before I finished the book.  I then realised that it would be a brilliant idea to expand this project beyond me and include work from other African writers, established and emerging.  

This is a non-profit venture and the podcast will be available to download for FREE from SoundCloud, iTunes and will be streamed from the project website once it has been designed.  

The reason I'm spearheading this project is twofold. Firstly, buying books in most African  countries is considered a luxury.  Add to that, the fact that libraries are practically  non-existent.  However, technology has made access to stories and culture possible through the internet and mobile phones.  So by making these stories available online for free, it means everyone and anyone will have access to these amazing stories without having to worry about cost.  

Secondly, making these podcasts enables me to share the stories from the African Continent and help our writers find a wider audience.  I believe there are tons of talented writers who give up because they can't find a publisher or don't have the platform and can't find an audience.  We're fortunate that we live in an age where technology has not only made it easier, but has also made culture more accessible.  This is what I'm hoping to provide, albeit in a small way through these podcasts, the ability for African writers to reach a wider audience and for that audience to discover the next generation of great African writers.   

Why You're Needed

I've already started the journey by using my own short stories to create the first four podcasts, but to continue we really need your help.  Your contribution will go towards paying for:

  • Writer, Actor and Producer fees
  • Website & Logo Design
  • Domain name & hosting
  • Legal fees (Writer & Actor contracts)
  • PR & Marketing
  • Recording studio costs
  • SoundCloud subscription
  • Composer

Our ideal goal is to make this a weekly podcast, however for now, we'll settle on producing the first two or more - depending on how much money we raise and take it from there.

The Perks

We really racked our brains on what perks to offer and we hope you like what we've come up with, these are mere tokens of our unending gratitude for your contribution and wish we could offer more.  Every single contributor will receive a twitter thank you and your name on the website Honour Wall once it's up and running, unless you wish to remain anonymous.

    It Takes a Village

    We realise that not everyone can contribute financially, that's okay because there are other ways you can help out.  We need you to make some noise, spread the word and talk about our campaign on all social media, forward to work colleagues, friends, family or even that person sitting next to you on the train reading a book.

    If you're a web designer and have some spare time to design our website, that would be awesome.  It would mean being able to spend the funds on making more podcasts.

    Same thing if you're a media lawyer, we need someone to draw up the writer & actor contracts.  If you're in Marketing & PR and would like to help out, please get in touch.

    Thank you for stopping by and please do spread the word.
story_txt:
Who & What I'm About Hi there and welcome to my Indigogo campaign page for raising funds to create podcasts of short stories by African writers.
The idea for this project came about when I created podcasts of some of the stories which are part of my upcoming short story collection.  The idea was to build up an audience before I finished the book.  I then realised that it would be a brilliant idea to expand this project beyond me and include work from other African writers, established and emerging.  
This is a non-profit venture and the podcast will be available to download for FREE from SoundCloud, iTunes and will be streamed from the project website once it has been designed.  


The reason I'm spearheading this project is twofold. Firstly, buying books in most African  countries is considered a luxury.  Add to that, the fact that libraries are practically  non-existent.  However, technology has made access to stories and culture possible through the internet and mobile phones.  So by making these stories available online for free, it means everyone and anyone will have access to these amazing stories without having to worry about cost.  
Secondly, making these podcasts enables me to share the stories from the African Continent and help our writers find a wider audience.  I believe there are tons of talented writers who give up because they can't find a publisher or don't have the platform and can't find an audience.  We're fortunate that we live in an age where technology has not only made it easier, but has also made culture more accessible.  This is what I'm hoping to provide, albeit in a small way through these podcasts, the ability for African writers to reach a wider audience and for that audience to discover the next generation of great African writers.      Why You're Needed I've already started the journey by using my own short stories to create the first four podcasts, but to continue we really need your help.  Your contribution will go towards paying for:

Writer, Actor and Producer fees

Website & Logo Design
Domain name & hosting
Legal fees (Writer & Actor contracts)
PR & Marketing
Recording studio costs
SoundCloud subscription
Composer

Our ideal goal is to make this a weekly podcast, however for now, we'll settle on producing the first two or more - depending on how much money we raise and take it from there.
  The Perks We really racked our brains on what perks to offer and we hope you like what we've come up with, these are mere tokens of our unending gratitude for your contribution and wish we could offer more.  Every single contributor will receive a twitter thank you and your name on the website Honour Wall once it's up and running, unless you wish to remain anonymous.


  It Takes a Village We realise that not everyone can contribute financially, that's okay because there are other ways you can help out.  We need you to make some noise, spread the word and talk about our campaign on all social media, forward to work colleagues, friends, family or even that person sitting next to you on the train reading a book.
If you're a web designer and have some spare time to design our website, that would be awesome.  It would mean being able to spend the funds on making more podcasts.
Same thing if you're a media lawyer, we need someone to draw up the writer & actor contracts.  If you're in Marketing & PR and would like to help out, please get in touch.
Thank you for stopping by and please do spread the word.

story:
"Living On A Prayer" is similar to the first book I wrote called "Tearing A New One: The Ins And Outs of Surviving Colorectal Cancer." It continues from where I left my readers, adding the personal struggle with the choice of continuing medical treatments, as strongly suggested by doctors, or face financial ruin trying to save my life. What follows for the next ten years, is an hysterically tragic tale of a single mother trying to keep her head above water, a roof over her head, and her possessions out of storage. Each of the seven deadly sins are featured prominently as chapters, recounting their roles in each of the households my youngest daughter and I took refuge in, and how each cardinal vice, for better or worse, has been a driving force that helped or destroyed our finances, emotions, relationships and sanity...and the eventual determination to better life for ourselves and those around us.

"Tearing A New One" was a moderate success for my first time as a self published author. I made about $4000.00 to date with that virgin attempt to tell a story I felt would not only free me from my fears, but maybe, just maybe, let a few people out there know that they are not alone, and that others in the world are going through what they thought was a world of isolation and discrimination. Countless letters have been received, thanking me for either enlightening a reader or comforting them . I am very, very, proud of that book. I edited that book myself, formatted it blindly enough to get it into Amazon Kindle and Barnes and Noble's Nook, and using Amazon's own Createspace to handle paperback copies for sale. Following that, was another moderate success: "The Five Most Aggravating Friends on Your News Feed." Royalties continue to be paid for both books, though sales have been extremely low since my devotion to "Living On A Prayer"

I am no longer a self-pub virgin.

My goal with "Living On A Prayer," is to reach out to the countless number of single parents that have been dealt a few hard blows in their life and let them know that they are not the only ones, whose friends, families and co-workers view them as a "liability" and that often times, more than not, the reflection in the mirror isn't always how others see us, but rather how our own view of our fading light is bounced, unknowingly, onto them.

I do not plan to Ebook this next venture for at least six months. My goal is to hardcover and jacket "Living On A Prayer," and sell such copies on my own, either through book signings, my own "bookstore"and pounding the streets and subways of NYC, if necessary to get sales. A hardcover, jacketed book has a look and smell that true book fans love and I predict that in the first three months I should be able to sell more than enough copies to cover costs.

That's where YOU come in dear donors!! I want to have this book professionally edited and marketed, along with a beautiful hardcover and dust jacket. It will take more than I can invest in at this time, but I assure you that the finished product will be profitable, but more importantly, reach out to others that are living on minimal means, trying to afford a Target purse in a Coach bag world.

Additionally, I would love to be able to tell you that 25% of all donations (if amount of total donations is above $1000.00), will be used to buy groceries, or help with a bill or two, for a single parent family, whose mom or dad is fighting cancer and out of work due to reactions to treatments, or surgery. I will be in contact at that time with a group called Stupid Cancer, to find out which one of their guest bloggers is in dire need. I will invite you to see how we help that family's life a little easier, through video and social media outlets.

I thank you in advance and I pray you have the faith to back me in this endeavor. 

Please take a look at the perks associated with each donation, as the higher the gift, the more reward will follow.

Thank you so much!

story:
Cliquez ici pour la VERSION FRANÇAISE



Saudis leasing thousands of hectares in Africa, US pension funds investing in the Amazon forest… a rush towards arable lands in the South is well underway. Agricultural development or neo-colonialism?

Land Inc. is a book project signed by TerraProject and Cécile Cazenave to be published by Editions Intervalles in Fall 2016 and traces a photographic journey across Brazil, Dubai, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Madagascar, the Philippines and Ukraine to document land grabbing and the growing investments in industrial farming.

Land Inc. - The background

In 2012, TerraProject collective, made up of 4 photographers, embarked in a 2 years journey to document the changing scenario of agricultural models in the world. With more people living in cities than in rural areas, and with growing interest by companies and corporations to invest in agricultural products, what is happening to those small-holder farmers in growing economies? What are the consequences of shifting from a family-run to an industrial farming model?
Is land grabbing the only option for agricultural development?

We have travelled to Brazil, Dubai, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Madagascar, the Philippines and Ukraine to meet, photograph and interview investors, farmers, government officials and human rights activists.

Land Inc - The book

Our photographic work had been published by several magazines as the first and only in-depth investigation on global land issues. Now the project is becoming a book, published by Editions Intervalles with two editions in English and French languages, and the written contributions by Cécile Cazenave, who interviewed seven experts to help us understanding the story behind this phenomenon.
The book, curated and designed by Mónica Santos, includes infographics by Studioburo. Cooperative PictureTank and Philippe Deblauwe have an active role in supporting and coordinating the production of the book.

Book format: 16,5 × 23 cm, 140 pages, 70 photographs.


The authors

TerraProject is an Italian collective of documentary photographers founded in 2006 by Michele Borzoni, Simone Donati, Pietro Paolini and Rocco Rorandelli. We are united by the desire to explore undocumented stories using a common stylistic approach. We have published 2 books, carried on 2 successful crowdfunding campaigns and won several prizes and grants including the World Press Photo (2010 and 2012), the Canon Prize (2010), the Pesaresi award for Contemporary Photograohy (2013) and the Graziadei Award (2014).

Cécile Cazenave has worked extensively on environmental and sustainable development. Energy, resources, pollution, agriculture, development and consumption are at the heart of her investigations and reports. 

The campaign

With the present campaign we aim at supporting the production of the book by pre-selling copies and offering rewards that will help covering the expenses for the project. Land Inc. is the first book on land issues and will represent a landmark in the topic for years to come. This project is not just about publishing a book, but about sparkling the debate on one of the most critical issues of the century.


GET A COPY!

We need your support to achieve this meaningful project. Pre-order one or more copies now and benefit from special discounts and rewards.
Please specify the language of choice (English or French) upon ordering the book.
Help us by spreading the word!

Rewards INFO
In addition to getting one or more digital or printed copies of the book, you can support the project by ordering some exciting rewards:

- Plant a tree: TerraProject, in collaboration with Treedom, gives you the opportunity to plant a fruit tree for one of their reforestation programs

in a dedicated forest in Kenia. 
Learn more by visiting the Kenia project page on Treedom website. 



- Get a bag: Studioburo has designed a dedicated bag for this campaign, printed on cotton.



- Hang a print: select one of the images from the Gallery tab to order a "35x35cm fine-art print" or a "60x60cm limited edition print" and hang them on your wall (framing not included).

Available prints can be chosen from the gallery tab

Please be so kind to send your selection to landinc@terraproject.net


Book COVER:



VERSION FRANÇAISE



Des Saoudiens qui exploitent des milliers d'hectares en Afrique, des fonds de pension américains qui investissent en Amazonie… C'est la ruée vers les terres arables du Sud. Développement agricole ou néocolonialisme ?

Le livre TERRES À VENDRE  signé TerraProject et Cécile Cazenave sortira aux Editions Intervalles fin 2016 et constitue un voyage photographique qui passe par le Brésil, Dubaï, l'Éthiopie, Madagascar, les Philippines, l'Indonésie et l'Ukraine documentant l'accaparement des terres agricoles et l'accélération des investissements dans l'agriculture industrielle.

Terres à vendre - la genèse du projet

En 2012 les 4 photographes du collectif TerraProject ont entamé un voyage de deux ans pour documenter les changements des modèles agricoles dans le monde. Alors que les populations urbaines dépassent en nombre les habitants des zones rurales et avec l'intérêt croissant des investisseurs pour les produits agricoles, qu'advient-il des petites exploitations dans les pays émergents ? Quelles sont les conséquences du passage d'une agriculture familiale à un modèle industriel ?

L'accaparement des terres arables est-il l'unique voie de développement ?

Nous nous sommes rendus au Brésil, à Dubai, en Indonésie, à Madagascar, aux Philippines, en Éthiopie et en Ukraine pour rencontrer, photographier et interroger fermiers, investisseurs, représentants des gouvernements et militants des droits d'l'homme.

Terres à vendre - le livre

Première investigation journalistique de fond sur les enjeux globaux liés aux terres agricoles, notre travail photographique a été publié par plusieurs magazines. Le projet devient à présent un livre publié, en version française et anglaise, aux Éditions Intervalles . 

  • Photographies : TerraProject
  • Textes et interviews : Cécile Cazenave
  • Direction artistique : Mónica Santos
  • Infographies : StudioBuro
  • Production : Scic Picturetank

Format : 16,5 × 23 cm, 140 pages, 70 photographies.


Les auteurs

Mu par le désir d'explorer des sujets peu ou non documentés dans un langage stylistique commun, le collectif TerraProject, fondé en 2006 par Michele Borzoni, Simone Donati, Pietro Paolini et Rocco Rorandelli, est devenu une référence de la jeune photographie documentaire européenne.  Leurs travaux ont été largement publiés et exposés, fait l'objet de deux livres et ont reçu de nombreux prix, tels que le World Press Photo (2010 et 2012), le Prix Canon (2010), le Prix Pesaresi pour la Photographie Contemporaine (2013) et le Prix Graziadei (2014).

Cécile Cazenave est journaliste, spécialiste reconnue des questions environnementales et du développement durable. Les énergies, la consommation, l'exploitation des ressources, la pollution, l'agriculture te le développement sont au coeur de ses écrits et investigations. 


La campagne participative

Par le biais de cette campagne de financement participative nous visons à soutenir la réalisation et la sortie du livre Terres à vendre. Nous vous invitons à pré-acheter l'ouvrage et proposons diverses contreparties en échange de votre soutien au projet.

Terres à vendre est le premier projet de livre documentant la ruée globale sur les terres agricoles et sera un ouvrage de référence pour les années à venir. Au delà de la publication, le projet vise à susciter et enrichir le débat sur un des enjeux les plus cruciaux du siècle.



SOUTENIR LE PROJET • PRÉ-ACHATS ET PARRAINAGE

Nous sollicitons votre soutien pour accomplir ce projet marquant. Pré-commander dès à présent un ou plusieurs exemplaires du livre Terres à vendre.
Merci de préciser le choix de la langue (disponible en version française ou anglaise)
Soutenez-nous en partageant l'information dans votre entourage !

INFOS SUR LES CONTREPARTIES
Réservez un ou plusieurs exemplaires du livre ou parrainez le projet en échange de contreparties additionnelles :

- Planter un arbre : TerraProject, en partenariat avec Treedom, vous propose de planter un arbre fruitier dans l'un de leurs programmes de reforestation en Kenia.
Plus d'infos sur la page du project Kenia dans le site Web Treedom. 


- Le sac Terres à vendre : cet élégant sac en cotton, a été spécialement conçu par Studioburo.



- Tirages photographiques : choisissez une photographie dans l'onglet Galerie pour commander un tirage "fine art en 35x35cm" ou un "tirage de collection numéroté de format 60x60cm" (les tirages sont livrés sans cadres).

Cliquez ici pour accéder à la galerie et choisir votre photographie.

Merci d'adresser ensuite votre choix par e-mail à landinc@terraproject.net

story:
My name is Shelly Dubois and I am a mother who has lost a child to cancer.  In 2006, my beautiful daughter Chantal was diagnosed with brain cancer and passed away in 2008. This book is my story.

A few months after losing my daughter, I searched for books or a blog on the internet in hopes of finding another mother’s story that I could relate to and somehow maybe help me with what I was going through.  To help me understand my pain and my grief.  My search found nothing.  A few years later, I felt that at some point, I would write a book of my story in hopes of helping others.  And here I am, I've written it and now its time to share it.

In my book, I talk about our lives at the time of her diagnosis, the events of treatments, trying to live a normal life, when she passed and how I dealt with my grief.

It is my hope that my story can reach out to mothers and fathers globally. There are many who feel alone and that they are the only ones who have had to experience this.  I hope they may find some comfort in relating to my story.


WHERE THE MONEY WILL GO:

Money raised through this campaign will be used for:

  1. Editorial Evaluation
  2. Professional back cover copywrite
  3. content edit
  4. copyright registration
  5. final proofread
  6. customer layout and premium cover design with front of the line service (inside, front and back cover)
  7. hardcover, paperback and ebook editions
  8. print and ebook distribution
  9. author website
  10. press release
  11. production team support
  12. marketing
  13. Indiegogo fees
ALL perks will still be honoured even if all the money is not raised. 


 PERKS - DRAGONFLY NECKLACE WITH BOOK

(Necklace might not be exactly as shown)

A dragonfly represents change and transformation – exactly what I have gone through since my daughter’s passing. A day after completing my book, without looking for it, I found a dragonfly pendant (I'm wearing it in my video) – in a shoe and accessories store that had one small cabinet with some jewellery in it.  It was perfect and for me, represented my change and transformation.  Another significance of my pendant – the middle stone is teal blue – my daughter’s favourite colour.  


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

You can help by sharing this with your friends on Facebook and other social media avenues, telling parents who have lost a child to cancer and telling people in your community about this campaign.

My name is Shelly Dubois and I am a mother who has lost a
child to cancer.  In 2006, my beautiful
daughter Chantal was diagnosed with brain cancer and passed away in 2008. This
book is my story.
A few months after losing my daughter, I searched for books
or a blog on the internet in hopes of finding another mother’s story that I
could relate to and somehow maybe help me with what I was going through.  To help me understand my pain and my grief.  My search found nothing.  A few years later, I felt that at some point,
I would write a book of my story in hopes of helping others.  And here I am, I've written it and now its time to share it.
In my book, I talk about our lives at the time of her
diagnosis, the events of treatments, trying to live a normal life, when she
passed and how I dealt with my grief.It is my hope that my story can reach out to mothers and fathers globally. There are many who feel alone and that they are the only ones who have had to experience this.  I hope they may find some comfort in relating to my story.WHERE THE MONEY WILL GO:Money raised through this campaign will be used for:
Editorial Evaluation
Professional back cover copywrite
content edit
copyright registration
final proofread
customer layout and premium cover design with front of the line service (inside, front and back cover)
hardcover, paperback and ebook editions
print and ebook distribution
author website
press release
production team support
marketing
Indiegogo fees

story:
Hi everyone,

Thank you for taking the time to stop by.

A bit about me:

I've had a long career as an actor with a lot of good fortune. I won an Emmy for Maggie's Secret, earned a nomination for a Genie in Love and Human Remains directed by Denys Arcand, written by Brad Fraser; a Gemini nomination for 9B, and  an ACTRA award nomination for the animated series, Toot And Puddle. In addition to my acting career, I am an activist with a passion and focus on equity issues, LGBT and women's rights. I have spent many days in protest, coffee shops, and on the streets, giving speeches about LGBT rights and raising awareness about child abuse, an issue very close to my heart. In 2004 I founded a nonprofit organization, Youth Out Loud, with the goal of raising awareness about child abuse. The annual event included a 4K march, a stage show, as well as an exhibition in Dundas Square of art and poetry created by youth who were survivors of abuse. 

Over the years I have developed an interest in writing. I was accepted into the Diaspora Dialogues Program in Toronto where I was mentored by novelist, David Layton. Since that time, I received a certificate degree through the Creative Writing Program at the University of Toronto, have written a short screenplay, His Name Was Steven, and a pilot about LGBT lives with my writing buddy Richard Jutras. 

 

The Memoir:

My career began as an eight year old in the sound studios for Sesame Street where the world of magic and make believe was my salvation. It wasn't until my teen years that reality hit and I quickly learned that surviving in an adult world on my own was going to be rough. I came out when I was young and my feminist politic mixed with the arts and activism kept me going. Childhood violence, eating disorders, sexism and homophobia, working in film, are all part of the story, and facing my mother so I could say goodbye. My memoir is about growing up female in a time when secrets and violence were 'normal' and deviating or speaking out was a risk. I took many risks.

Sample writing from the memoir:

"The palliative care ward was quiet. My mother was in and out of consciousness, her eyes glassy, hollow, her body bruised from multiple needles and the insertion of the intravenous saline to which morphine was added when her pain broke through. The rooms of the dying were small and sterile with no color, just bodies, wires, oxygen masks, gray speckles in the floor. I entered and sat beside my mother's bed, where I had covered parts of a wall with images of the natural planet, perhaps it was to remind me of my own life and to give my mother something beautiful to look at in her own quiet moments alone. Maybe it would calm her or maybe she could imagine herself in the images themselves, in Africa with animals, or by the edge of a cliff, or winged, able to see form a bird's eye view.

Sometimes mother and I would stare into each other's eyes as if we were thinking or feeling the same things, looking for a way to speak to each other, the pauses filled with a lifetime of stories desperate to come out, but now, nothing."

 What Is Needed & What You Get

The funds will not only help me while I'm rewriting, but will be used for publicity and outreach. Every penny will be used wisely. I deeply want the book to be successful and for all who contribute to feel good about their contribution. There will also be a dedicated website created for the memoir and updates will appear on this campaign page as well as on social media platforms.  

NOTE: You will receive an email from the crowdfunding page which will be your receipt. 

Perks! 

You will get a copy of the book when it is published, recognition, invites to the launch and, or if a book club meeting is desired, we can arrange that too.

 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Please help me raise funds to meet my goal and beyond. If you can't contribute directly, maybe you can share this campaign with your email list or on your FB page, Twitter account, or Instagram. However you can help is appreciated! 
    • You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!  

        THANK YOU!

story:
¿Qué?

La puerta sin voz es una de esas novelas corales en las que el lector puede escoger un protagonista o, quizás, identificarse incluso con uno o varios de ellos...

Ambientada en Salamanca, la novela trata de una familia donde el padre abusa de una hija y maltrata a su mujer; una banda de delincuentes que atracan la sucursal de una caja, un grupo de estudiantes de primero de Medicina con su alegría y sus frustraciones, unos pacientes que luchan por sobrevivir y un comisario de policía que intenta averiguar quién mató a...

Con personajes tan  diversos todos convergen tarde o temprano arrastrados por el destino.

¿Quiénes?

Tandaia es una joven editorial con voluntad de cambio, de dar la alternativa a autores que no la encuentran en otro lugar, con nuevas y refrescantes ideas como es el crowdfunding.

De este modo eres tú, ahora que te estás planteando cómo colaborar, el que decide si la obra que te presentamos verá la luz pasando a formar parte de nuestro catálogo... porque consideramos al lector parte fundamental del proceso.

Hoy te presentamos a Ángel Montes Valero.

Nacido en Madrid el día 9 de Enero de 1941. Licenciado en Medicina por la Universidad de Salamanca y Licenciado en Estomatología por la Universidad de Madrid. Médico acupuntor y presidente de A.L.A.I.D.A.M. Fundador y presidente de la ONG Mano Amiga. Titulo de bibliotecario y documentalista. Premio de Teatro Rojas Zorrilla de 1998 por la obra AExurge Domine@. Finalista del premio Everest de novela en el año 2012 con la novela Ka’anyumil. Escritor de varias novelas, cuentos, obras de teatro y guiones cinematográficos.

¿Cómo?

Para arrancar el proyecto nos hemos fijado como objetivo 880€; esta es la cantidad que recaudaríamos si alrededor de cuarenta mecenas se hiciesen, cada cual, con un ejemplar de esta primera edición.

  • Teniendo acceso a las galeradas de edición.
  • Recibiendo un ejemplar semanas antes de la salida al mercado de la obra.
  • Si bien, también podrías ver tu nombre en los agradecimientos aportando un poco más.

Los fondos recaudados, se utilizarán para sacar adelante esta primera edición de La puerta sin voz que saldría después a la venta.

Además...

Sabemos que son tiempos difíciles, también nosotros los sufrimos, y es posible que no te encuentres en disposición de apoyarnos con tu mecenazgo en estos momentos... pero esperamos que si esto te ha llegado al alma, incluso si tal vez conoces en persona al autor, trates de difundir esta campaña (facebook, twitter, blogger, boca-oreja... ) para que alcancemos nuestra meta y Ángel Montes Valero vea publicada su obra.

Gracias por vuestro tiempo.

story:
My name is Lindsay Brumwell. I am a Mohawk woman, originally from Tyendinaga Mohawk Territory, Ontario, Canada. I am passionate about writing, and wish to share my gift with others in hopes that they will find a powerful lesson within it to help them in some way. Hence, the birth of my first book, The Unshackled Soul: A Shy Gal's Guide to Self-Confidence. I have struggled with my shyness throughout my entire life, and this book is my attempt to help myself overcome my shyness and live a life that is most expressive of my true self. It is my hope that through the reading of my story, and my tips and tricks for overcoming shyness, others will begin to harness the power they possess within to create great change within their lives. 

Where do you come in? In order to flourish to the greatest degree, I would like to see my book available in three formats; print, e-book and audio. This would enable it to reach the largest audience of readers possible. It is my hope that readers of all levels can access and benefit from my book. In order to make my dream of doing this a reality, I need your support. It is quite costly to produce a book in all of these formats. It will cost approximately $2300 for the print edition (including marketing, etc), $100 for the e-book edition, and $3200 for the audio version. I would be eternally grateful for any financial support you could provide, but also would love it if you could just help me spread the word about this exciting new book. 

Why should you believe in this project? Why should you believe in me? Because I believe in it. I believe in me. I also believe in empowering others. This book will not only impact the lives of others by the simple act of reading it, but also it is my intention to deliver workshops on the topic of self-confidence to assist young men and women. Many fiction books allow us to escape into a new world, it is my hope that this book will provide an entrance to a world yet uncovered. That world is our inner world. The one where we can make the biggest changes in our lives.

"Believe in yourself and you will soar beyond your dreams." ~ Kathleen Manderville

Come soar with me! 

Thank-you!

story:
Mantid Magazine is an arts and literary publication celebrating artists, writers, and media creators from various backgrounds who illustrate the power of diversity through their identities and their work. The magazine was created to celebrate unique/alternative/underground entertainment media, and to serve as a platform for marginalized groups in the arts (women, LGBTQA, people of color, and the differently-abled). Mantid focuses on publishing genre work including weird fiction, horror, dark fantasy, magic realism, and dark science fiction. Our ultimate goal at Mantid is to foster a diverse creative community and to bring unique, fiercely human voices to the forefront of modern speculative storytelling.

We are a group of long-time fans and creators of genre work who have come together to welcome people from all over the world into the weird and speculative fiction communities.

What We Need & What You Get
Printing Costs: $1000

Paying Artists/Writers/Contributors $800+

The inaugural issue of Mantid Magazine will be a print publication, due in Winter 2015. If the magazine does well, subsequent issues will be in print and online.

If we don't reach our goal, the funds collected will be put aside while further funds are raised in order to print the magazine. In the meantime, we will post the content to the Mantid Magazine website, set to be launched on December 1st, 2015.
   
The Impact
There have been many discussions about what the weird fiction and art communities can do to welcome in people from all over the world, and the most logical solution is to create a platform where people from all walks of life are welcome and encouraged to submit work.


Risks & Challenges
Our biggest challenge in starting something of this magnitude from scratch, apart from the technical aspects of printing and design, involves attracting media creators to contribute their works to the magazine and attracting a big enough audience to make the magazine an ongoing venture. In addition to unknown artists, writers, and media creators, we would also like to include the works of writers who are already known in the weird fiction community. To do this, we need two things. Demand for the content, and funding to bring them in. We know that we can achieve this goal with your help.

While we are presently only offering copies of the magazine as payment to contributing writers and artists, we hope that with additional funding, we can offer monetary payment as well.

Be Part of the Inaugural Issue
We are currently seeking contributions that fall under the umbrella of Mantid Magazine’s core subjects. All writers are welcome to submit, but special priority is given to writers who are women, LGBTQA, people of color, and/or the differently-abled.

What we are looking for to fill our Winter 2015 issue:

ARTICLES 

Articles should be between 1,500 and 10,000 words.

We are seeking both opinion and academic articles discussing subjects involving diversity in media. Some topics include film theory, art theory, gender equality/feminism, sociological/psychological perspectives on art trends, the impact of art on social change, etc. Topics centered around the horror, science fiction, fantasy, and/or magic realism genres are encouraged.

SHORT FICTION/POETRY 

Stories should be between 1,500 and 10,000 words. Poetry should be under 1,000 words.

Work should fall under one or more of the following genres:

Horror

 Dark Fantasy

 Dark Science Fiction

 Dark Fairy Tales

 Magic Realism

 Surrealism 

Avant-garde

 Experimental

Diverse characters are encouraged. Stories with gratuitously violent or sexual content will not be considered.

PHOTOGRAPHY/ART WORK

The strange and avant-garde will be given special priority over more commercial work. Some art movements that we appreciate include:

German Expressionism 

Symbolism 

 Surrealism

Avant-garde

 Cubism

 Bauhaus

 Conceptual Art

Works with thematic elements drawn from horror, fantasy, science fiction, and/or magic realism are preferred. Make it weird!

Works that emphasize the beauty and power of diversity are highly encouraged.

No submission fee. Payment will be in contributor copies. Submissions should be in .doc, .docx, or .pdf format. Names should be included on any manuscripts/images.

ARTICLES/FICTION/POETRY DEADLINE: October 15th, 2015

PHOTOGRAPHY/ART WORK DEADLINE: November 1, 2015

Publication Goal: December 1, 2015

Know someone who might be interested in contributing? Tell them about us!
Submissions and any questions may be sent to mantidmagazine@gmail.com

Other Ways You Can Help
While we appreciate any and all donations, we also understand that it isn't possible for everyone to contribute money to the campaign. We would appreciate it just as much if you would share the campaign page, and/or tell your family, friends, and colleagues about us!

Thank you!

story:
The Story Behind This Book & the Movement To Help People Get Healed

My name is Floyd Prescott III.  I am 31 years old and currently serving as in ministry as a pastor and president of Restoration Life Ministries International.  I have been actively involved in ministry and community service since age 17.  One aspect of my ministry and service to the community, local & abroad, is to see people get restoration and healing from hurts experienced, especially in the emotional arena as it relates to hurts sustained in relationships, particularly when it comes through church-based relationships.  Years ago, I was a victim of this, and I know many others personally who have been damaged by this as well; but, God has restored me and has moved me forward to serve and help, in part, others who are suffering through this type of experience.  So, I am introducing this project to NOT ONLY SELL BOOKS, but also help raise funds these funds so that I can help others get healed and restored.  I recently completed the writing of a book that will help people through this.  

The Impact of this Issue & WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

Here is why your help is important:  an estimated 22 million adult Americans no longer go to church because they were hurt either by church leadership or someone they met or knew through prior church attendance.  This number does not include their children, nor does it include those who are hurt but still attend church (I know some of these type of people personally).  Therefore, your contribution will help to have an impact potentially in many many lives.  

What We Need & WHAT YOU GET

Simply put--I am attempting to raise as much money as possible to help with PROMOTING the book and also HOSTING A 2-3 DAY CONFERENCE to minister to this area extensively!  As you can see, with the number of people affected around this country, that this is a MAJOR ISSUE that needs to be addresses more extensively.  I personally know many people affected by this, some of which have emotional issues resulting from this.  So, with the limited reach I have, if I know many people affected, I am certain that there are many, many more.  Would you help?  In return for your contribution/donation, you will get a copy (or copies, ebook or printed) of the book, signed by me (if printed).  Also, if you would like to be involved in the preparation for our conference next year, please let me know.

ALSO, if you are a BUSINESS OWNER & would be interested in contributing to this cause or HELPING TO SPONSOR THIS CONFERENCE next year, please let me know.  The more money we raise, the more people we can help.  Book release date is Monday, October 17, 2011.  Please help us!  

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP OUT

Share this campaign with others, including pastors & church leaders & also go to the website --www.floydprescott.com and share that website with others.  There, you can read my bio, a portion of the book & see some of the heart behind why God had me to write the book.  Also, email me from the website with stories of your experience in this area if you have any, along with whether or not you still struggle or your story of how God healed you!  


ALSO, IF YOU WOULD LIKE TO CONTACT ME, PLEASE DO SO VIA MY WEBSITE (LISTED ABOVE).

Also, add us on twitter - @Healn4theChurch

story:
WE MADE OUR GOAL! THANK YOU!

Because my supporters are amazing, we reached our minimum goal, which means that regardless of the level at which you donated, you will be receiving a digital copy of Undeliverable when they are ready. 

Now let's see if we can push that even higher! Our stretch goals are:

  • $2000 - everyone gets a free digital copy of Thea of Oz
  • $3000 - everyone gets miniposters of the art from Thea of Oz
What you are helping fund now is professional audio recording to make an audio book of Undeliverable, as well as more press kits and review copies. Thank you!


The Book

When Benjamin Grant’s son disappeared a year ago, he felt it was his duty as a father to do everything in his power to find his son, and he tried. He threw himself into the search, but his obsession left him without a home, wife, or job. Now, he’s managed to find work at the United States Postal Service’s Mail Recovery Center, which he hopes will prove an invaluable tool in his search. With the help of Sylvia—a kleptomaniac artist—Ben learns the ins and outs of a warehouse full of lost mail and explores every lead in his son’s case. But when that investigation leads him to the monster, Leonard Moscovich, Ben fears the worst.

Undeliverable is a literary novel of 70,000 words, completed in part for my Master’s thesis at Emerson College. I graduated in May of 2011, after completing my thesis under the direction of Steve Yarbrough and Pablo Medina. Before my passion for writing led me to Emerson, I earned a B.A. in English and Psychology at Willamette University. My previous publications including a handful of short stories, creative non-fiction pieces and poetry in various online and print journals and I have worked with various publications such as Redivider at Emerson and Unstuck.

I chose to go the crowd-funded route instead of pursuing traditional publishing for two reasons. First, I disliked the amount of control I had to give up to the publishing houses and the amount of rights I would basically have to forfeit as a first time author. Secondly, I found the industry oddly reticent to back a book where a portion of the proceeds were going to charity, and that was something I was determined to do. $1 from each sale is donated directly to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, so while you join Ben on his journey to find his son, you're also helping families across the country find their own missing children. And yes, for every person who donates at the $25 dollar level and above during this campaign, a dollar will be donated to the Center.


What people are saying about Undeliverable:

“Undeliverable delivers a range of pleasures to its readers: a unique and fascinating setting, an urgent mystery, a cast of oddball characters, sharp and witty dialogue. But what makes it compelling above all else is its heartfelt exploration of one man’s grief and determination in the face of his son’s disappearance. We yearn for Ben to find his missing boy, but even more, we want him to find a path to fulfillment in a world full of trouble. In Rebecca Demarest’s hands, his journey is tense, thrilling, and deeply satisfying.”
          - Scott Nadelson, author of Saving Stanley and The Cantor’s Daughter 

“Herman Melville knew that the dead letter office of the U.S. Postal Service was a potent metaphor for modern life.  His short story, “Bartleby the Scrivener,” harnessed the great sighs of humanity found there.  Rebecca Demarest’s engaging tale of what has become the “Mail Recovery Center” picks up the beautiful sadness and loss of a place that contains letters to “Santa, Jesus, God, Satan, The Perfect Man, [and] The Easter Bunny…”  Her tale is framed engagingly by the “Property Office Manual” instructions by the long gone Gertrude Biun, a ghost of bureaucracies past.  Rebecca Demarest knows how tales work.  She gives her readers spirited language, dead-on humor and a trip to the inner workings of despair and strangeness.  Serious readers will love this book.”
          - Michael Strelow, author of Henry: A Novel of Beer and Love in the West

“A modern noir with a social conscience, Demarest’s novel combines the page-turning qualities of the “man on a mission” thriller with the heartwrenching realities of child abduction. Publishers, and fans, of cinematic fiction with a something extra, take notice.”
          - William Orem, playwright and author of Killer of Crying Deer


What We Need & What You Get

Here's what we need the money for, in order of importance (that is, order in which they will get funded depending on how much money we receive):

  • Proofreading - making sure those pesky typos don't make it into the final product!
  • Spots in Kirkus Review, Publisher's Weekly, and the Portland Book Review.
  • Ebook conversion - paying for professional conversion to ensure the best reading experience for digital readers.
  • Marketing campaign including sending out free digital copies to libraries across the country and digital and postcard campaigns.
  • Press kits to send out along with review copies of the novel to as many reviewers as possible.

You'll see to the right what you'll get at each level, but here is a brief description of the various prizes available:

  • Mini-poster of the cover - You'll receive a postcard poster of the cover of Undeliverable to post on your fridge or to dress up your cubicle. 
  • Hard copy of Undeliverable - Just what it says. You'll get a paperback of the novel before the official launch date.
  • Thea of Oz is a short story set in the Wizard of Oz Universe and illustrated by Jason Morgado. Its the beginning of a whole new series that takes place in the not-so-distant future and includes some of your time-honored favorite characters, some you probably don't remember from the original series of novels, and a few brand new ones.


The Competition

Here's where we liven things up. We'll be running a competition over the course of the campaign. When you refer your friends, family members, coworkers, spouses, pets, and intergalactic contacts to this page, make sure they either message me, make a note on the discussion board, or make a note on their paypal transaction that mentions you by name, because the person who refers the most people to the campaign is automatically upgraded to the level of "Property Clerk" and wins an original framed print from Thea of Oz, signed by Jason Morgado. How awesome is that? So start referring your friends today! 

  • First Place: Framed print from Thea of Oz, copy of Thea, and a personalized copy of Undeliverable
  • Second Place: personalized copy of Undeliverable and a copy of Thea of Oz

story:
Summary

A while back, Manuel and Molly appeared in my apartment. They're both sentient plush animals, apparently from a parallel universe (Earth-33, to be precise). Manuel is a lobster, and Molly is a sheep: Manuel's BFF, and also his accountant. 

Since February 2017, Manuel has made it impossible for me to socialize, have a relationship, or even enjoy a quiet evening at home. From using my credit card to buy "anti-prawn devices" (read: cocktail umbrellas), to jumping out of the drawer and scaring the living daylights out of EVERY SINGLE DATE who comes over, my level of done with Manuel is very high. 

With Molly's help, I figured out how to get rid of Manuel. 

Apparently, Manuel can only return to Earth-33 if this book is read by at least 420 people. 

I need your help to do this. 

 

These are some other reasons why I'm writing and publishing this book:

  • I am a Cylon, and my Cylon therapist said I should publish a book. Do you have any idea how much worse anxiety is with countless copies of yourself out there?
  • Manuel (the lobster) will not shut up until I publish this book, because everything is always about him. ALL THE TIME.
  • I will be eternally grateful to you for ending the current misery of waking up to feel Manuel's grubby, furry lobster claws on my face, pestering me about writing and publishing his story.


(Manuel also likes throwing loud parties and inviting questionable wildlife into my home, including very drunk mermaids. And no, he does not pay rent.)

Please, please help me get rid of this dratted crustacean once and for all.

 

What I Need & What You Get

Apart from my sanity, this is what I need:

  • I need at least 420 people to read this book. According to Molly, this is the magic number that's needed for them to go back to Earth-33, where Manuel will presumably continue to pester my Earth-33 counterpart.
  • Dear Earth-33 version of me, I apologize in advance, but I need my life back. #sorrynotsorry
  • The dazzling array of perks I have laid out include being featured in the book (using your own name or a character name of your choice). This is an excellent opportunity to be a part of inter-parallel universe travel without the help of psychotropic substances. It's also cheaper, hooray!
  • What you get: Apart from the perk you've purchased, all backers will be mentioned in the acknowledgment section, with your preferred name. You can make up a name if you like, but please don't make me say "Thanks, Khaleesi!" 7 times on one page. 
  • The story: You'll find out how on earth Manuel arrived here at Earth-42, and the palaver that my predecessor on Earth-11, Penny Lane, had to go through to get rid of him. (Yes, that is really her name.) 
  • You'll get updates throughout the campaign, mostly about how Manuel is continuing to make my life a misery. 
  • Post-campaign: you'll get updates on the book production, as well as delightful visual anecdotes of how Manuel is cheerfully continuing to ruin my life.
  • Where the funds go if I exceed my basic and stretch goals: From whatever's left after covering my basic and stretch goal costs, 11% will go to a literacy NGO that you, the backers, will choose via a poll. The rest will go towards offsetting the enormous debt that Manuel has racked up on my credit cards, along with more sessions with my Cylon therapist.
  • Oh, you wanted numbers? Okay then. Molly has some numbers for you.

 

  • Basic goal:
    • Interior layout for ebook and print, cover design, print costs for backer copies and distribution on all major online retailers: USD $1,400
    • A Goodreads giveaway for 42 print copies: USD $600
    • Total: USD $2,000
  • Stretch goal (up to USD $8,000)
    • Everything in the basic goal plus:
    • Developmental editing so that more people will enjoy reading this book, review it positively, and tell people about it, thus getting me closer to the minimum goal of 420 readers needed to rid myself of this meddlesome lobster: USD $4,400
    • Marketing budget boost, spread out over 3 months: USD $1,200
    • Sending copies of the book to 30 book bloggers and reviewers, including printing and shipping: USD $400
    • Total: USD $8,000

 

The Impact

This is how your contribution will help me and other people on Earth-42:

  • SRSLY PLEASE, help me out. Manuel has ruined about 83 dates (and counting) for me already. He keeps appearing at awkward times and throwing his voice from the drawer that I've stuffed him in. A squeaky voice yelling "Kill the prawns!" in the middle of a make-out session is super not fun. Believe me.
  • ^^There was one time Manuel did this when I was about to get erm, romantic with a guy who looked exactly like Pedro Pascal. I never saw NotPedro again (after he fled, screaming). Do you have any idea how difficult it is to find a Pedro Pascal lookalike in Singapore?
  • This is my first time crowdfunding. Not my first time writing a book, though. (You can read it here.)
  • You can trust me to get rid of the lobster once I hit the 420-reader target. Bye, Manuel!

 

Risks & Challenges

These are the risks and challenges in my quest to remove Manuel from my life and my apartment:

  • If Manuel had told me about the 420-reader threshold, this campaign would be moot, because he would totally be lying. However, Molly has verified that this is the magic number needed for both the creatures to go back to Earth-33, so I think we're good.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you know anyone who can travel to parallel universes, remember: sharing is caring!
  • If you don't know a parallel universe traveller, please share this campaign anyway.
  • If funding this campaign isn't your thing, that's fine. All I ask is that you read  and review the book when it's published, so that the confounded crustacean can be on his way back to Earth-33 yesterday. 

 

Get updates on the campaign page or here:

https://fb.me/manuelthelobster

https://www.instagram.com/manuel.thelobster/

 

So long, and thanks for all the fish.

 

* * * 

 

Extract from Manuel And Molly Find Earth-42

 

Chapter 1: Implausible Coconuts

 

Penny Lane was not happy.

She was late for work, and it was a drippy, dreary Friday. One of her heels was threatening to abscond forever, and it was about two wobbles away from breaking. Penny thought about the annoying ads for mints which contained unnecessary amounts of cheeriness and impractical advice about shoe-related emergencies, and wondered exactly what narcotics the models had been on.

“Miss! I have a message for you!” someone babbled behind her. A clammy hand landed on her shoulder. It was so slippery with sweat that Penny managed to shrug her way out of the unwanted contact almost instantly.

She spun on her heel, which broke — presumably out of sheer spite. The apparent owner of the clammy hand was a man in his twenties who looked about as high as one can get without being dead.

“I don’t want the message. Go away!” Penny snarled. The effect of her hostility was somewhat ruined as she awkwardly balanced on one leg to break off the offending heel — just like in those implausible mint ads. She wanted to scream, but the front of the frozen yoghurt shop was possibly not the place to do this. There were several children there, and they looked like the sort that might join in for the fun of it.

The man’s pupils were the size of saucers. He looked like he might have some complex theories about saucer deities as well. “But I just wanted to sing for you!” he said, looking slightly hurt.

Penny Lane gritted her teeth. “I see. Well, I’m not really a fan of musicals. I’m really late for work, so I’ll just-”

“STRAWBERRY FIELDS FOREVERRRRRR!” the man shrieked. Even the most charitable human in the world could not truthfully term this as ‘singing’. No, it was nowhere close to singing. It was more of a horrid banshee wail so awful that it had probably ripped a hole in the space-time continuum. Or at least, Penny thought so. This might seem an unkind assessment, but Penny Lane had been subjected to a ridiculous number of unimaginative Beatles-related jokes, puns, and comments about her name for twenty-four years. What made it even worse was the fact that she actually liked their music, but years of wordplay-induced trauma had made her unable to listen to an entire Beatles song without throwing up.

“Look!” she said, feigning excitement. “It’s a giant lollipop in the sky!”

The man turned away to look for the giant lollipop. Penny fled the scene.

 

***

 

The moment Penny walked into the office, she understood that she had made a colossal, costly error.

She had entirely forgotten about Friday Funday at the office.

Friday Fundays were the demented brainchild of her boss, Mr Eddy Eddington. For some reason, he thought that forcing all his employees to wear costumes for a different theme every Friday was a good idea. Savage words like ‘team morale’ and ‘interdepartmental dynamics’ had been thrown around recklessly in several agonising meetings about Friday Fundays. How exactly this would help a team of seven people at a paperclip distribution company was a mystery for the ages.

Today wasn’t just any Friday Funday. It was the Beatles-themed Friday Funday.

Bob from Marketing greeted Penny with a level of enthusiasm bordering on insanity. Penny considered his incessant cheerfulness a grave personal insult, and made the effort to be laconic when interacting with him.

“Penny! We renamed the goldfish!” Bob said, almost vibrating with joy.

No, thought Penny. Please don’t say it. Don’t-

“We named them John, Paul, George, and Ringo!” Bob giggled. He then skipped off to torture someone else in the office with his excessive happiness.

Penny surveyed the scene in the office while a silent scream began in her head. It did not stop: the office had turned into her personal hell. There were about four Ringo Starrs, one Yoko Ono, and Beatles-themed decorations everywhere.

Miranda from Sales swanned over to the receptionist’s desk. She was dressed as Yoko Ono, and inexplicably, was wearing dramatic fake eyelashes that were compromising her center of gravity.

“Penny!” she squealed. “Darling, you poor thing! Did you forget about this week’s theme?”

Penny wondered, not for the first time, if there was a supply of Prozac in the office pantry that no one had told her about. Miranda blinked rapidly at her, causing a very small breeze.

“Miranda, I think Paul is flirting with the intern again,” Penny said, edging towards the cover of her reception desk. Miranda’s head swiveled towards a gaggle of Paul McCartneys.

“Which Paul? Paul, Paul or one of the McCartneys?” Miranda asked.

At this point, Penny Lane mentally ran through a number of ways to escape this nightmare, some more violent than others. It took her about three seconds, and these were her options:

 

One: Curl up into a small ball under my reception desk and go unnoticed until lunch hour.

Two: Bribe the security guards to activate the building’s fire alarm.

Three: Dramatically announce a fake plot twist to the half-eaten sandwich conspiracy from last Thursday, and slip away in the chaos.

Four: Simply walk out of the door, and face the consequences on Monday.

Five: Use all of the very sharp pencils in my stationery supply box to stab everyone, and somehow flee without getting eventually arrested.

Six: Pretend I’m going to get everyone coffee and doughnuts from the bakery, and just go home instead.

 

Penny didn’t really have the stomach or the motor skills coordination for option five. Just as she was weighing the pros and cons of the doughnut gambit versus the sandwich conspiracy plan, the phone at her desk rang.

With chirpiness that she didn’t know she possessed, Penny answered the phone. “Good morning, this is The Accidental Paperclip Company,” she trilled. “Penny Lane speaking, how may I help you?”

A woman on the other end of the line yawned before replying. “Yeah, I’m calling from the Angel of Mercy Hospital about Eddy Eddington. Penny Lane — you’re his next of kin, right?”

Penny blinked rapidly. “Er, I’m n-” she began, before the gears in her mind started whirring. “Yes, I am. What’s happened?”

“Coconuts,” the woman said.

“What?” Penny said. She was having trouble hearing the woman, as one of the Ringos was now serenading Ringo the goldfish, singing “I wanna hoooold youurrr fin,” at an unreasonable decibel.

“Collided with a truck of coconuts. We need you to come to the hospital and sign some forms,” the woman said, stifling another mighty yawn. “It’s urgent,” she added.

“I see. I’ll be there in thirty minutes. Bye,” Penny said. She tried not to sound happy about this, but failed. She grabbed her handbag and headed for the door, wondering if she should still try the sandwich conspiracy option, just to shake things up a little.

“Emergency, can’t talk, see you on Monday,” she said to no-one in particular. Penny Lane smiled as the office door swung shut and the voices of her bewildered colleagues faded into silence.

 

***

 

“Yeah, just sign here,” the nurse said, thrusting a clipboard at Penny. She glanced at the form, then at the inert figure on the hospital bed. Eddy Eddington was lying there with his eyes wide open, seemingly unresponsive to any stimuli. The next bed was empty, unless you counted a plush sheep and a slightly grubby plush lobster.

“Hang on, are you very sure he’s brain-dead?” Penny asked. She couldn’t quite believe the words coming out of her mouth, as she had often wondered about Mr. Eddington’s brain activity; i.e. if there was any activity at all, and how he managed life in general when he was far less intelligent than a slice of bread.

The nurse shrugged. “He’s passed all the tests. Or failed them, depending on how you look at it.”

Penny edged closer to Eddy Eddington and decided to do something quite cruel.

There are a few possible reasons for what she did next, and some of them are unsavory. It could have been the sheer volume of Beatles-related trauma. It could have been an allergic reaction to the young man who had attempted to sing to her. It could have been pent-up rage from a relentless onslaught of Friday Fundays, each theme more annoying than the next — particularly if one took public transport to work. It could have been the memory of the cactus-themed Friday Funday that pushed Penny over the edge. It was also possible that Penny was trying to confirm that Eddy Eddington was truly brain-dead (in the medical sense, at least).

Penny knew that Eddy Eddington had a phobia of plush toys. She even knew why: it had something to do with an office Christmas party several years ago, a singing telegram messenger in a bear costume, a traumatic breakup, and obscene quantities of very cheap tequila.

Penny knew that he was violently terrified of plush animals. So she placed the plush lobster and sheep on his hospital bed, very slowly and deliberately. And she waited.

She waited for the screams, the uncontrollable shivering, the tears, but there was … nothing. There was simply a shell of a man who held the dubious honor of having been the most annoying human on the planet.

Penny wanted to feel sorry for him, she really did. She tried. But she simply couldn’t.

She could, however, sign the form ensuring that he received adequate healthcare, should he wake up within the next 48 hours — an extremely unlikely situation, given his lack of a reaction to the lobster and the sheep.

A tiny pinprick of guilt stopped her just before she signed the form. “Are you sure you don’t need my ID?”

The nurse blew a large, purple bubble. It popped, and he continued chewing. “Nah,” he said. “I mean, why would anyone pretend to be his relative?”

Penny had to admit that the nurse made a good point. She signed the document, half-expecting Eddy Eddington to spring to life moments later. He did no such thing, and instead, was wheeled off to another section promptly.

If Penny hadn’t had such a strange day, she might have caught a very important detail: the plush lobster and the sheep weren’t on Eddy Eddington’s bed when the orderly whisked him away.

As she walked down the hospital corridor, Penny conceded that it hadn’t been such a terrible day after all. She promptly revised this opinion after a burly nurse bumped into her and hurried off without an apology. She thought she heard him saying “prawns” in a squeaky voice as he skulked off, but that made no sense at all.

Somewhere near the radiology wing, Penny heard the squeaky voice again. “Prawns!” She stopped walking. It was entirely possible that her day had been stressful enough to cause auditory hallucinations, although she’d never had any before.

Penny dashed into the first bathroom she saw. She put her handbag down on the next sink and splashed her face with water.

“All right, Penny, pull yourself together,” she said out loud. Thankfully, her reflection did not respond.

Instead, the clasp of her handbag popped open. This time, she heard it clearly. Someone — or something — squeaked from her bag, “Kill the prawns!”

There was a shushing noise, and then a slightly trembling voice said, “Manuel, be quiet!”

At this point, Penny was more curious than she was afraid. She was also considering the possibility of a visit to the psychiatric wing in the hospital, but it was a vague possibility.

She reached out for her handbag, because saying “Hello? Who’s there?” the way characters do in horror movies was just silly. She peered into her handbag and saw one gleaming eye first. Then another, and finally, two pairs of eyes, staring back at her nervously.

The plush lobster and the sheep were in her bag.

The sheep cleared its throat. “I’m so very sorry to trouble you, miss,” the sheep said, “but it appears that my calculations have gone rather awry. We appear to have landed on Earth-11 instead of Earth-33. Do you think you might possibly help us to get home? I would be much obliged.”

The lobster waved its claws at Penny. “Kill the prawns!” it squealed.

Penny looked at the creatures, then at her reflection. She pinched herself very hard. “Ow!” she said. Penny looked at her handbag again. The creatures were still there. The lobster was still waving its claws furiously and demanding prawn slaughter.

“I see,” Penny said, and meant it.
